so let's start with a very quick
introduction of what we do at CERN
what's our goal what our objectives are
so CERN operates the world's largest
particle accelerator which is called the
LHC which stands for large headron
collider as you can see on this small
animation it took me way longer than I
wanted to to make it we we accelerate um
proton beams to nearly the speed of
light and as you can see it's um an
accelerator which is built underground
around 100 mters under the French and uh
Swiss border under the city of Geneva
and why are we doing this we want to
deepen our understanding about
fundamental uh physics we want to know
more about the building blocks of nature
and of of the
universe which consists of different
kinds of particles and all the forces
that act between
them so how do we do this after we
accelerate the particles in our big loop
which is like around 30 km
circumference we let them collide at our
experiment
sites and what we do here is we use the
high energy of the particles that they
that they got during
acceleration and transform the energy
into mass by creating new new kinds of
particles
and those can like range from like
particles that you maybe know from
school protons neutrons electrons but
also to more exotic particles like pions
ions and
neutrinos this process acts at like 40
million times per second so the whole
machine operates at 40 MHz and if you
want to read out all the data that's
available to us we will end up with
around 40 to 50 terabytes per second
which is too much to be handled by our
current capacities so for that reason we
employ a filtering process which is a
so-called trigger system which consists
of two levels first the level one
trigger which is a hardware based um
filter selection process where we just
use simple rules to discard events that
are not very interesting to us so for
example if you have an collision event
with a very high energy that's something
that we want to keep and that's
something that we want to store events
with a low energy is not interesting to
us there's no new
physics so we will discard it after this
first step we we step into the level two
trigger system which is a software based
um approach which runs in computing
farms very close to the actual uh
collision
point after this part we end up with
around a few gigabytes per second that's
something that we can handle and that's
something where the end data will go
into long-term storage
and now recently we started a research
and development project which is called
the next generation triggers where we
want to employ machine learning based
methods on
improving the whole chain so the goal
will be to use machine learning
models in the first step in the level
one trigger but also in the second step
in the uh second level

working on these trigger systems so we
